Title: Bibliografia Internazionale Leonardiana in CD-Rom
Topics: Leonardo, da Vinci, 1452-1519--Bibliography
Notes: 'Bibliografia Internazionale Leonardiana on CD presents the bibliographical records of works by and on Leonardo published in Italy and abroad (writings, apocrypha, critical and facsimilie editions of drawings and manuscript, anthologies, monographs, miscellanea, analyses of monographs and journals) . ' -- Jacket ; BIL: Bibliografia Internazionale Leonardiana in CD ; BIL: Bibliografia Internazionale Leonardiana on CD is part of the on-line archive of the International bibliography of Vinciana edited by the Leonardo Library of Vinci, which includes: the complete catalogue of the library's Centre for research and documentation for studies on Leonardo, up-dated to the current year; a continually growing reference section dedicated to the sources of Leonardo's works, to the Renaissance, the history of technology, of science and of art; some book and epistolary collections of Leonardo researchers or connected to him; the catalogue of the heritage possessed until 1989 by the Ente Raccolta Vinciana in Milan and the Carlo Viganò collection of Vinciana at the Università Cattolica deel Sacro Cuore in Brescia; the bibliographical records derived from the most well-known repertories on Leonardo, their integration and up-dating through the library's research activity and the collaboration of scholars. The complete on-line archive of the Bibliografia Internazionale Leonardiana, or International bibliography of Vinciana, can be consulted on the Internet site of the Leonardo Library ; Title from disc label

Name: di Giorgio, Francesco, of Siena
All names: Taccola, Mariano, c. 1382-c. 1458 [author] ; di Giorgio, Francesco, of Siena, 1439-1501 [author]
Title: Compilation of treatises on natural philosophy and mechanics, and numerous mechanical designs
Physical description: A paper codex ; Materials: Paper. Watermarks are visible on ff. 7 and 8 (see C. M. Briquet, Les Filigranes: Dictionnaire Historique des Marques du Papier dès leur Apparition vers 1282 jusqu'en 1600, 4 vols (London: Quaritch, 1907), nos 6645-6659) that suggest an origin in Italy 1445-1484. Dimensions: 300 x 205 mm (text space: 240-260 x 180 mm [ff. 1-20]). Foliation: ff. 1-261 (+ 8 modern flyleaves at the beginning + 6 at the end); plus 6 blank leaves after f. 14; 1 blank leaf after f. 17, 2 blank leaves after f. 20, 1 blank leaf after f. 104, 1 blank leaf after f. 204, 4 blank leaves after f. 250, 1 blank leaf after f. 251, 1 blank leaf after f. 255. An older foliation, now struck out, also exists; the number sequences are: '1-14', '16-113', '115-214', '216-267'; plus one blank leaf after ff. '14', '113', '214', and 11 leaves after f. '267'. Collation: 9 singletons (ff. 1-9), i 10-1+1 (ff. 10-14, plus 5 blank leaves after f. 14; the 6th leaf is missing and has been replaced with a blank modern paper leaf), two singletons (a blank leaf and f. 15), ii 8 (ff. 16-20, plus one blank leaf after f. 17, and two after f. 20), singleton (f. 21), iii-iv 12 (ff. 22-45), v 10 (ff. 46-56), 3 singletons (ff. 57-59), vi 8 (ff. 60-67), 5 singletons (ff. 68-72), vii 6 (ff. 73-78), 4 singletons (ff. 79-82), viii 10 (ff. 83-92), 3 singletons (ff. 93-95), ix 8 (ff. 96-103), 4 singletons (ff. 104-106, plus 1 blank modern paper leaf after f. 104), x 8 (ff. 107-114), 3 singletons (ff. 115-117), xi 10 (ff. 118-127), 3 singletons (ff. 128-130), xii 8 (ff. 131-138), 2 singletons (ff. 139-140), xiii 12 (ff. 141-152), 2 singletons (ff. 153-154), xiv 8 (ff. 155-162), 3 singletons (ff. 163-165), xv 10 (ff. 166-175), 2 singletons (ff. 176-177), xvi 10 (ff. 178-187), 2 singletons (ff. 188-189), xvii 10 (ff. 190-199), 2 singletons (ff. 200-201), xviii 10-1+1 (ff. 202-210, the 4th leaf is missing and has been replaced with a blank modern paper leaf), 2 singletons (ff. 211-212), xix 10 (ff. 213-222), 2 singletons (ff. 223-224), xx 10 (ff. 225-234), 2 singletons (ff. 235-236), xxi 10 (ff. 237-246), 4 singletons (ff. 247-250), four bifolia (ff. 251-253, plus four blank leaves before f. 251 and one blank leaf after f. 251), xxii 4 (ff. 254-257), 3 singletons (ff. 258-255, plus one blank leaf after f. 255), 1 bifolium (ff. 260-261). Script: Gothic cursive. Binding: Post-1600, British Museum binding. Brown leather with gold tooling on the spine
Notes: This manuscript contains a compilation of treatises on natural philosophy and mechanics along with numerous mechanical designs, principally selections from the works De ingeneis (1433) and De machinis (1449) by the Sienese engineer Mariano Taccola (b. c. 1382, d. c. 1458), and the Codicetto (?1460s-70s) by the Sienese architect Francesco di Giorgio (b. 1439, d. 1501), who is named in the manuscript three times (f. 17v, 129r, 194v). It also contains some otherwise unattested designs. The final portion of the manuscript (ff. 252r-261r) is an addition from the 1st quarter of the 17th century (f. 259r is dated 1612). ff. 1r-8v: Treatise on hydrostatics. ff. 9r-12r: Treatise on qualities of various kinds of earth and water. ff. 12r-14v: Treatise on minerals. ff. 15r.-17v: Recipes for inextinguishable fire. ff. 18v- 20v: Marcus Graecus, Liber ignium, followed by recipes concerning fire. ff. 21r-250v: Mechanical designs. ff. 252r- 261r: Designs for architectural work in SS Annunziata in Florence and the Certosa of Pisa, early seventeenth century. Decoration:. Numerous mechanical designs in outline drawing, usually tinted with brown, pink and green washes, including apparatus for scientific experiments, hydraulic systems, devices for moving heavy loads, mills, fortresses, siege machines, weapons, devices for crossing water, carpentry joints, devices for catching fish, devices for operating bellows, chimneys, a sheepfold, battering rams, ladders, ships, fountains, a centaur costume, diving suits, parachutes, canons, clocks, surveying techniques, systems for raising columns, architecture (ff. 3r, 4r-8v, 13v, 21r, 22r-103v, 104r-126v, 128r-v, 130r-175r, 176v-182v, 183v-201r, 202r-203v, 204r-249v, 250r-v, 253r-v, 254v-256r, 257r, 258r, 259r, 260r-261v)
Provenance: Origin: ?Siena, Italy. Pietro Bigazzi, 1869: named as the owner by Angelo Angelucci at the time of his examination (Angelucci, Documenti inediti (1869), p. 84). Sir John Charles Robinson (b. 1824, d. 1913), museum curator and art collector: named as the source of acquisition on first flyleaf, 'Purchd of Sir J C Robinson 15 Dec. 1891.' (f.), and in the British Museum Department of Manuscripts records of minutes and acquisitions, which notes the price of £200

All names: Speyer, Edward, banker, patron of music and art, 1839-1934 [former owner]
Title: SPEYER CORRESPONDENCE. Non-musical correspondence and papers of Edward Speyer (d. 1934), amateur of music and art, viz.:- (1) Miscellaneous autograph letters from Arthur James Balfour (1st Earl of Balfour 1922), Sir Charles Wentworth Dilke, 2nd Bart, M.P, George Joachim Goschen, 1st Viscount Goschen, (chiefly relating to the production of the latter's book The Life and Times of Georg Joachim Goschen ... 1903), William Holman Hunt, Sir Frederick Pollock, 3rd Bart. (f. 3b), William Barclay Squire, William Butler Yeats, arranged alphabetically, together with the menu of a dinner given by Sir Henry Thompson, 1st Bart, on 17 Feb. 1904, endorsed with his signature and those of the guests (f. 24). ff. 1-24b;- (2) Correspondence, mainly addressed to E. Speyer, arranged alphabetically, relating to his proposal, made in The Times of 9 Mar. 1914, for the building of an annex to the National Gallery to house the cartoons of Raphael, Mantegna, and Leonardo da Vinci from the Victoria and Albert Museum, Hampton Court Palace, and the Royal Academy of Arts, respectively. Among the writers are Charles Aitken, Director of the National Gallery, Laurence Binyon, Deputy-Keeper of Prints and Drawings, British Museum, Sir Herbert Frederick Cook, 3rd Bart, George Nathaniel Curzon, Earl Curzon, Charles John Holmes (knt. 1921), Director of the National Portrait Gallery, and Sir Edgar Vincent, K.C.M.G. (Viscount D'Abernon 1926). Included at ff. 48-52b are press cuttings, and records of a question asked in the House of Commons on the same subject. ff. 25-52b. Names of writers are given in the Index to the present Catalogue. Paper; ff. 52. Quarto. 1899-1926. Presented by Edward Speyer, Esq, in 1931, together with Add. MS. 42233, and reserved until 1948

Name: Insanguine, Giacomo, called 'Monopoli', composer
All names: Alberti, Domenico, composer [author] ; Alessandri, Felice, composer [author] ; Anfossi, Pasquale, composer [author] ; Insanguine, Giacomo, called 'Monopoli', composer [author] ; Scolari, Giuseppe, composer [author] ; Vinci, Leonardo da [author] ; Zingarelli, Nicolò Antonio, composer, 1752-1837 [author]
Notes: (1-8.). ROYAL MUSIC COLLECTION. Opera movements; late 18th century. With symphonies and accompaniment for instruments as listed below, in score. Paper. 1.10 ff. Insanguine (Giacomo) called Monopoli : [Didone] Non ha ragione ingrato. Aria; with strings. The date of performance is inaccurately given as 1770 at the S. Carlo theatre in Naples, but it was actually 1773. 2.16 ff. Scolari (Giuseppe): [Antigono] A torto spergiuro. Aria; with oboes, horns and strings. The date of performance is given in Naples at the 'S. Carlo, 1766'. 3.16 ff. Alessandri (Felice): (Demofoonte) Sperai vicino il lido. 'Aria Seria, con Recitativo'; with strings. 'Per Il Sigr Luigi Marchesi In Padova'. 4.32 ff. Anfossi (Pasquale): Son Regina disperata. Scena, consisting of recitative, cavatina and aria; with horns, trumpets, flutes (traversi), oboes and strings. 5.24 ff. Zingarelli (Nicolo Antonio): (Nittete) Guardami padre amato. Terzetto; with strings. 6.23 ff. Zingarelli (Nicolo Antonio): (Montezuma) Saldo scoglio. 'Aria Seria'; with oboes, horns, bassoons and strings. 7.8 ff. Alberti (Domenico): (Temistocle) Ah frenate il pianto imbelle. Aria, with strings. 8.18 ff. Vinci (Leonardo): (Medo) Sento l'ombra del mesto Germano. Aria preceded by a recitative; with horns and strings. includes:. Tract 1 Giacomo Insanguine, called 'Monopoli'; composer: 'Non ha ragione ingrato', aria from [Didone]: 18th cent: Ital: Copy; Tract 2 Giuseppe Scolari, composer: 'A torto spergiuro', [from 'Antigono']: late 18th cent: Ital: Copy; Tract 3 Felice Alessandri, composer: 'Sperai vicino il lido', aria from 'Demofoonte': aft. 1783?: Ital: Copy; Tract 4 Pasquale Anfossi, composer: 'Son Regina disperata', scena: late 18th cent: Ital: Copy; Tracts 5, 6 Nicolò Zingarelli, composer: Vocal music: late 18-early 19th cent: Lat, Ital: Copies; Tract 7 Domenico Alberti, composer: Vocal music: 18th cent: Ital, Lat: Copies; Tract 8 Leonardo da Vinci: Vocal music: 18th cent: Ital: Copies

Name: Sarri, Domenico, composer

Notes: (1-10.). ROYAL MUSIC COLLECTION. Opera arias and duets; 18th century. With symphonies and accompaniment for instruments as listed below, in score. Paper. 1.7 ff. Sarri (Domenico): Sà il mio cor. Duet; with strings. 2.6 ff. Porta (Giovanni): Cara, addio, morir mi sento. Duet from an opera; with strings [For another contemporary copy see R.M.23.d.8.(26.)]. 3.4 ff. Vinci (Leonardo): Dimmi una volta. Duet; with strings. 4.8 ff. Hasse (Johann Adolf): Io ti lascio. Duet; with strings. 5.8 ff. Hasse (Johann Adolf): [Alessandro nel Indie] Se mai piu saro geloso. Duet; with strings. 6.6 ff. Hasse (Johann Adolf): [Artaserse] Tu vuoi ch'io viva, o cara. Duet; with strings [For a contemporary copy see R.M.23.f.2.(21.)]. 7.4 ff [Porpora (Nicolo Antonio)]: Ah se non vivi o cara. Fragment of a duet, lacking introduction and conclusion; with string accompaniment [The middle pages of the aria which is item 8 below.]. 8.4 ff. Porpora (Nicolo Antonio): [Alessandro nel Indie] Se viver non poss'io. Duet; with strings [Fragment: the middle pages of this aria are item 7 above. For another contemporary copy see R.M.23.d.8.(21.).]. 9.10 ff. Porpora (Nicolo Antonio): Temi lo sdegno mio. Terzetto from an opera; with strings. 10.10 ff. Giacomelli (Geminiano): Vuo'vendetta. Notes: (1-31.). ROYAL MUSIC COLLECTION. Opera arias and duets; 18th century. With symphonies and accompaniment for instruments as listed below, in score. Paper. 1.4 ff. Alberti (Domenico): [Olimpiade] Che non mi disse un di. Aria; with strings. 2.8 ff. Capranica (Matteo): Luci amate. Aria inscribed 'per il Sigr Gizziello', performed at the Argentina theatre, 1746; with strings. 3.6 ff. Anon: [Didone] Cadra fra poco in cenere. Aria inscribed (in a different hand from the text) 'Sigra Americhi, 1724'; with strings. 4.2 ff. Anon: So che tu l'ami. Aria; with figured bass only. 5.8 ff. Albinoni (Tommaso): Sei mia speme, mio tesoro. Aria performed at the Capranica theatre and entitled 'Aria nona anno 1726'; with strings. 6.2 ff. Sarri (Domenico): Cruda a me! che tanto t'amo? Aria; with bass only. 7.2 ff. Duni (Egidio Romualdo): (Il Nerone) Ti servi io tiranno. Aria performed in the Tordinona theatre, Rome, 'nella Primavera, 1735'; with violin and figured bass only. 8.16 ff. Araja (Francesco): Ritorna ai di sereni. Aria; performed 'nel teatro delle dame'; with instruments. 9.2 ff. Feo (Francesco): Si mio bene al tuo bel core. Aria; with bass only. 10.6 ff. Feo (Francesco): (Ipermestra) A che da te lontano. Aria performed at the Alibert theatre, 1728; with strings. 11.2 ff. Feo (Francesco): Sempre il fulmine. Aria; with bass only. 12.2 ff. Pergolesi (Giovanni Battista): [Olimpiade] Che non mi disse un di. Aria performed in the Tordinona theatre, 1735; with figured bass only. 13.2 ff. Giacomelli (Geminiano): (La Nitocri) Qual sconsolata. Aria performed at the Tordinona theatre in Rome, 1736; with violin and bass. 14.2 ff. Costanzi (Giovanni Battista): Dal caro tuo pastor. Aria; with bass only. 15.2 ff. Manna (Gennardo): [Artaserse] Non conosco in tal momento. Aria performed in 'Napoli 1743 Teatro Reale'; with violin and bass. 16.4 ff. Giacomelli (Geminiano): Ah non partir t'arresta. Duet performed at the Tordinona, 1736; with violins and a bass. 17.4 ff. Giacomelli (Geminiano): E puoi, crudel, lasciarmi. Duet performed in 1731; with strings and bass. 18.2 ff. Leo (Leonardo): Spera spera Dorinda. Aria; with bass only [For another copy in score see R.M.23.e.2.(19.)]. 19.6 ff. Leo (Leonardo): Spera spera Dorinda. Aria entitled 'Ottava di Capranica 1726; with strings and bass [For a copy in short score see R.M.23.e.2.(18.)]. 20.3 ff. Giacomelli (Geminiano): Per te perdo. Aria inscribed 'Capranica. Per il Sigre Monticelli, 1731'; with strings. 21.4 ff. Porpora (Nicolo Antonio): Non lascia il ben. Aria; voice part only. 22.4 ff. Capua (Rinaldo di)?: Io non so se amor tu sei. Song; with bass only [For a contemporary copy see R.M.23.e.8.(23.)]. 23.8 ff. Anon: Soave pensiero. Aria; with two string orchestras. 24.4 ff. Metastasio (Pietro): La Liberta a Nice. 4 arias; with bass accompaniment only. 'Del Sigr Pietro Metastasio Musica Di diversi Autori', the composers are Costanzi, Pellegrini, Colista and Giura. 25.15 ff. Anon: Arsinda. Fragments of recitative and aria from the first and second acts of the opera; with bass only. Several pages have been crossed out and corrected, and the script varies. 26.2 ff. Anon: Amor dover rispetto. Aria; with bass only. 27.4 ff. Anon: [Alessandro nel Indie] Se mai turbo il tuo riposo. Duet; with bass only [RISM: Leo (Leonardo) from the opera 'Alessandro nell'Indie']. 28.2 ff. Anon: Or ch'a morir m'invio. Voice part only, [?performed at]'Capranica 1743'. 29.1 f. Anon: Infelice in questo. Last verse of an aria; with bass only. 30.1 ff. Vinci (Leonardo): [Artaserse] Vo solcando il mar crudele. Aria, performed at the Alibert theatre in 1730 (Opa 2a); with bass only [For another contemporary copy see R.M.23.f.2.(16.)]. 31.6 ff. Vinci (Leonardo): (Artaserse) Per quel paterno amplesso. Aria, performed in 1730; with strings. includes:. Notes: HALL GRIFFIN PHOTOGRAPHS. Vol. III (ff. 100). Black-and-white photographs, with commentary, quotations and pen-and-ink maps, of the settings and related subjects for Browning's poems Pippa Passes, Andrea del Sarto, Fra Lippo Lippi and La Saisiaz, and postcards to illustrate The Pied Piper of Hamelin . 1. ff. 1-38. Pippa Passes . Photographs and notes of and relating to the ancient Venetian city of Asolo, the setting for Pippa Passes, written after Browning's first visit there in 1838, and of the surrounding area including the villages of Orcana and Possagno, and of Canova's studio in Possagno. B.M. numbering: 1937-12-23-5 (1-37). 2. ff. 39-49. Andrea del Sarto . Photographs and notes mostly of and concerning the artist's paintings. B.M. numbering: 1937-12-23-6 (1-10). 3. ff. 50-62. Fra Lippo Lippi . Photographs and notes of paintings by various artists. B.M. numbering: 1937-12-23-7 (1-12). 4. ff. 63-85. La Saisiaz . Photographs and notes of and concerning the chalet of La Saisiaz, near Geneva, where Browning stayed in 1877, and of the surrounding area: Collange sous Salève; the mountain La Salève; the Arve and Rhone valley, and Geneva. B.M. numbering: 1937-12-23-8 (1-21). 5. ff. 86-100. The Pied Piper of Hamelin . Black-and-white and coloured postcards of Hamelin (Hameln). B.M. numbering: 1937-12-23-9 (1-14). includes:. ff. 2-17, 25-34 Asolo, Italy: Annotated photographs of Asolo: circa 1900; ff. 18-24, 38 Possagno, Italy: Annotated photographs of Possagno: circa 1900; ff. 20, 22-24, 36-37 Antonio Canova, sculptor: Art. Miscellaneous: Photographs of his studio and temple in Possagno and of his tomb in Venice: circa 1900; f. 35 Art. Portraits: Caterina Corner, Queen of Cyprus: Titian, painter, draughtsman and printmaker: Portrait by Titian of Caterina Corner: circa 1542: Photogr. circa 1900; ff. 36-37 Venice: Annotated photographs of buildings and monuments in Venice: circa 1900; ff. 42-46, 49 Art. Miscellaneous: Andrea del Sarto, painter and draughtsman: Paintings by Del Sarto: early 16th cent.: Photogr. circa 1900; f. 47 Leonardo da Vinci: Art. Portraits: Self portrait by Leonardo da Vinci: early 16th cent.: Photogr. circa 1900; f. 48 Art. Portraits: Giorgio Vasari, painter, architect and writer: Self-portrait by Giorgio Vasari: mid 16th cent.: Photogr. circa 1900; f. 51 Art. Miscellaneous: Masaccio, artist: Florentine Frescoes by Masaccio: circa 1427: Photogr. circa 1900; f. 52 Art. Miscellaneous: Orcagna, painter, sculptor and architect: 'Triumph of Death', painting by Orcagna: mid 14th cent.: Photogr. circa 1900; ff. 54, 55, 60, 62 Art. Miscellaneous: Fra Filippo Lippi, artist: 'Coronation of the Virgin', painting by Fra Filippo Lippi: 1439-1447: Photogr. circa 1900; f. 57 Saint Mary,; the Blessed Virgin: Art. Portraits: Cimabue, painter and mosaicist: Portrait of the Virgin and Child by Cimabue: late 13th cent.: Photogr. circa 1900; ff. 65-85 Art. Photographs: Hamelin, Hanover: Photographs and postcards of Hamelin: circa 1900

M.] Rossetti, speaking of the work of Leonardo da Vinci, and thanking Rossetti for the gift of a copy of his Italian Courtesy-Books, 1869; 10 March 1870 [ Ashley Library Catalogue, iv, p. 189.]. includes:. f. 167 William Michael Rossetti, author and art critic: Leonardo da Vinci: John Ruskin, author, artist and social reformer: Letter to [W. M?] Rossetti from John Ruskin rel. to Leonardo da Vinci: 1870

Olivier Archive. Vol. DCCXXXVIII (ff.). Proposals 1950-1959. Includes proposals for biopics of Shakespeare, Edmund Kean (for 20th Century Fox); Lawrence of Arabia (for Nomad Productions); Leonardo da Vinci, and William the Conqueror. Other notable proposals included: A tale of two cities, and Tender is the night, both for Selznick; My cousin Rachel ; Andre Obey's Noah, for Alexander Korda; War and peace; Bridge on the River Kwai, for Horizon Pictures; and several Shakespeares, most notably Antony and Cleopatra, for a team including Filippo del Giudice and Dallas Bower; but also including King Lear (also for del Giudice), As you like it. Troilus and Cressida, and Macbeth

John Gielgud Archive. Professional photographs mostly relating to films and television programmes; 1932-1978. Includes pictures from The Good Companions, Conversation at night, The secret agent, Hamlet, Julius Caesar, Saint Joan, The shoes of the fisherman, The charge of the Light Brigade, The mayfly and the frog, In good King Charles's golden days, Hassan, Lost horizon, documentary on Leonardo da Vinci, Deliver us from evil, QB VII, 11 Harrowhouse, Disraeli, and Gold

Name: Collins, Dorothy Edith, secretary to G K Chesterton
All names: Collins, Dorothy Edith, secretary to G K Chesterton, 1895-1988 [author]
Notes: G. K. CHESTERTON PAPERS. VOL. CXX B (ff. 117). Poems without titles, arranged in order of the opening words of the text, followed by fragments. Mostly drafts, autograph unless otherwise stated. Contents:. 1. ff. 1-2. 'A voice from Leeds will rouse amain each prehistoric prehistorian'; 1926. Three stanzas. Two typewritten copies, one with autograph amendments. Published as 'Darwinians at play' in C.W, vol. 10, [part 1], p. 432. 2. f. 3. 'Alone, alone on the sunny world'; circa 1895. Three stanzas. Published as '[Alone, alone]' in C.W , vol. 10, part 3, p. 29. 3. f. 5. 'Armed with the message of the lips of God'; circa 1892. Seventeen lines, with other lines deleted. Probably a draft of 'St Francis Xavier'. See also Add. 73305 A, and Add. 73319 A for other drafts. 4. ff. 6-8. 'Blue with the bloom of darkest grapes the night'; circa 1926. Twenty-two lines. 5. f. 9. 'By influenza vanished by good ban' [i.e. 'By influenza banished my good man']; circa 1898. Four stanzas. Published as '[The Wedding]' in C.W, vol. 10, part 2, p. 259. Followed by 'I can attest the wedding happened' on f. 9v. 6. f. 10. 'Casements glimmer at sunset'; circa 1893. Five stanzas. Published as '[Soul of my soul]' in C.W, vol. 10, part 2, p.112. 7. f. 11. ''Dust to dust' the old-world story curst us for our father's deed'; circa 1892. Eighteen lines. Published as 'Dust to dust' in C.W, vol. 10, part 3, p. 9. 8. ff. 12-13. 'Earth is a prey of the hours'; circa 1892. Six stanzas. Published as 'Impermanence' in C.W, vol. 10, [part 1], p. 54. 9. f. 14. 'Far from the Player's Club but not in play'; 1926. Two stanzas. Typewritten copy of lines sent to Margaret Halford, Christmas 1926. Published as 'The Player's Club' in C.W, vol. 10, [part 1], p. 312. 10. f. 15. 'For the children is the challenge of the giant', inscribed 'Duplicate of chorus for play'; circa 1910. Two stanzas. Typewritten copy . Published in C.W, vol. 10, [part 1], p. 199. 11. f. 16. 'From the crowd of the worldlings moulded in the image of mode & of power'; circa 1892. Twenty-two lines. A fuller version beginning 'From the lips of the priestly fawners' is to be found in Add. 73320 A. 12. f. 17. 'Go on ye gay, whose rotting sins are marked with a painted pride'; circa 1892. Six lines. 13. f. 19. 'Here we bring in paper furled'; circa 1899. Eight lines. 14. ff. 20-21. 'I know a monstrous city'; circa 1910. Eight stanzas. Published as '[Small things]' in C.W , vol. 10, part 2, p. 194. 15. f. 22. 'If I could sing as you could sing'; circa 1895. Two stanzas. On a flyleaf cut from a book. Published as 'If I could sing' in C.W, vol. 10, [part 1], p. 53. 16. f. 23. 'If only the Princess Mary / Had worn the garb of a Guide'; circa 1930. Twenty lines. Typewritten copy of an original owned by Marjorie Biggs. Published as '[On the wedding of the Princess Royal]' in C.W, vol. 10, part 3, p. 309. 17. f. 24. 'In the mystic hour of the evening in the low red of the west'; circa 1892. Twenty lines. Published as '[The Mystic Hour]' in The G.K. Chesterton Quarterly, no. 36 (Spring 2007), p [4] and as '[The Minstrel]' in C.W , vol. 10, part 2, p. 107. 18. f. 26. 'Into steep towers the storm is gathered in'; circa 1929. Two stanzas. Published as '[The Storm]' in C.W , vol. 10, part 3, p. 389. 19. f. 27. 'Leave to the proud Lamotte'; circa 1892. Eight lines. Followed by a fragment of an essay on craftsmanship on f. 28. 20. ff. 29-30. 'Love is enough for the loving, love without self's alloy'; circa 1892. Ten stanzas. A fuller version is to be found in Add. 73320 A. Three stanzas published as '[Love is enough]' in C.W, vol. 10, part 2, p. 41. 21. ff. 31-32. 'Love, we have looked on many shows'; [1926]. Seven stanzas. Published in C.W, vol. 10, [part 1], pp. 357-358. 22. f. 33. 'Mother, shrewd of heart & tongue'; circa 1898. Seven stanzas and part of a line. Possibly the poem to seven women mentioned in Return to Chesterton, p. 38. Reworked as an untitled poem on his friends, see Add. 73348, ff. 107-109, and as 'The legend of the good women', see Add. 73345 B. With a copy of Unwin's Literary Notes for 9 Aug. 1898 on the verso, possibly written by Chesterton. 23. ff. 34-34*v. 'Not often I linger as now, for weeping is not for me'; circa 1892. Six stanzas. Published as '[Weeping is not for me]' in C.W, vol. 10, part 2, p. 103. 24. ff. 35-36. 'On an undiscovered island / Lives an Economical Man'; circa 1895. Five stanzas. Published as 'Economics' in C.W, vol. 10, [part 1], pp. 433-434. 25. f. 37. 'Search in the boxes: where close pressed'; 1931. Four lines, annotated by Dorothy Collins that this was written to her at Los Angeles when Chesterton's evening suits could not be found. 26. ff. 38-43v. Sketches, among which are four lines beginning 'Set the sun beside the moon'; circa 1895. 27. f. 44. 'Shade of high shame and honourable blindness'; circa 1919. Three stanzas. Published as 'True lovers' in C.W, vol. 10, [part 1], p. 374, and revised as 'A wedding in war-time', published in The Eye-Witness, vol. 14, no. 339 (2 May 1919), p. 11. 28. f. 45. 'She was doubly distinct'; circa 1927 . Four lines on an illustrated card. 29. ff. 46-47v. 'Sing of the Great Lord Archibald'; 1885. Six stanzas. Published as 'The Great Lord Archibald' in C.W, vol. 10, [part 1], pp. 44-45. 30. ff. 48-50. 'So careful of the type she seems'; 1932. Five stanzas. Autograph, copying the original inscription by Chesterton in Dorothy Collins's copy of Chesterton's Christendom in Dublin, with a photocopy of the frontispiece of The Spice of Life (1964) showing the original inscription. Also published as 'To Dorothy - on her birthday - with love' in C.W, vol. 10, [part 1], p. 322. 31. ff. 51-52v. 'Sweet Jonathan's wont was to say'; circa 1892. Forty-two lines. Published without the lines headed 'David' as 'Sweet Jonathon' in The G.K. Chesterton Quarterly, no. 30/31 (Spring/Summer 2004), p. 13. 32. ff. 53-54. 'The clotted woods are dim: the day'; circa 1917. Four stanzas. Part of the poem 'Warsash, 1917' in Add. 57983 C, ff. 34-36. Published in The G.K. Chesterton Quarterly, no. 23 (Summer 2002) and in C.W , vol. 10, part 3, p. 263. 33. f. 55. 'The golden leaves of autumn drift deep over valleys'; circa 1892. Four lines. With chapter headings for the story 'Prince Lucio' on the verso. 34. ff. 56-58. 'The king sat lonely in the tower'; circa 1890. Eleven stanzas. Published as 'The king of day' in The G. K. Chesterton Quarterly, no. 8 (Autumn 1998), p. 15 and in C.W, vol. 10, part 2, p. 41. 35. f. 59. 'The little fields of green & gold'; circa 1895. Three stanzas. Published as 'Green leaves' in C.W, vol. 10, [part 1], p. 217 (see also 'World lover' at Add. 73333 B). 36. f. 60. 'The little sardines of the tin'; circa 1904. Six lines. Headed 'Briton or Boer' and 'Sardines'. Published in M. Ffinch, op. cit, p. 83 and as 'Kruger' in C.W, vol. 10, [part 1], p. 59. 37. ff. 61-62v. 'The red sun glimmered low'; circa 1892. Seven stanzas. Followed (ff. 62-62v) by seven stanzas of an untitled poem, 'Stricken to death'. Published as '[The Treatise]' and '[The Death of Roland]' in The G.K. Chesterton Quarterly, no. 30/31 (Spring/Summer 2004), pp. 10, 14 and in C.W , vol. 10, part 2, pp. 121-122. 38. f. 63. 'Then I turned into a palace, where in spangled bowers secluded'; circa 1892. Three stanzas. Published as '[Inferno]' in C.W, vol. 10, part 3, p. 9. 39. ff. 65-68. 'Then spake the journalist as one that dreams'; circa 1917. Eleven stanzas and fragmentary verses. Drafts for 'Fragment (from Tennyson's 'Idylls of the Queen', 'The passing of Freda')' of which the fair copy is at Add. 57983 C, f. 16. Published in C.W , vol. 10, part 3, p. 269. 40. ff. 69-70v. 'Through the city, through the highways went the artist'; circa 1892. Fifty-two lines. A continuation of 'Leonardo da Vinci' in Add. 73321 C. Published in The G. K. Chesterton Quarterly, no. 7 (Summer 1998), p. 15. 41. ff. 71-72. 'To be another, his race to run'; circa 1893. Nine stanzas. Typewritten copy, with imperfect autograph which includes stanzas 3, 4, 7 and 8. Published as 'To be another' in C.W, vol. 10, part 2, p. 140. 42. f. 73. 'To horse, to horse & away lads, the frost is white & hoar'; circa 1891. Fifty-two lines. Published as '[Marston Moor]' in C.W , vol. 10, part 2, p. 46. 43. f. 75. 'To the speed and to the stooping of the eagles'; n.d. Two stanzas. Typewritten copy . 44. f. 76. 'We set our feet on the necks of kings'; n.d. Two stanzas. Typewritten copy of verse written in a copy of John Ruskin, The Seven Lamps of Architecture (1894). Published as 'We set our feet' in C.W , vol. 10, part 2, p. 85. 45. f. 77. 'Weicht zacht gemeine herren geuze zein'; circa 1897. Two stanzas. Published as 'On himself' in C.W, vol. 10, [part 1], pp. 457-458. 46. f. 78. 'What, Enid, was your soul's mystic hour?'; circa 1926. Four stanzas. Typewritten copy . Published as 'Enid, an invitation' in C.W, vol. 10, [part 1], pp. 274-275. 47. f. 79. 'When Earth and all her seers were sad'; n.d. Four stanzas. Typewritten copy of verses written in 1894 in Chesterton's copy of R. L. Stevenson, Virginibus Puerisque, now at the G. K. Chesterton Library, Plater College, Oxford. Published as 'The child' in C.W, vol. 10, [part 1], pp. 198-199. 48. ff. 80-81. 'When folk shall find, as it is fated', with an explanatory note; 1921. Ten lines. Published as '[A Prophecy]' in C.W , vol. 10, part 3, p. 308. 49. f. 82. 'Whence are thou come o flower'; circa 1892. Four lines. 50. f. 83. 'Where suns & stars like lamps that burn, encircle the space untrod'; circa 1892. Three stanzas. Published as '[The Live-long day]' in C.W , vol. 10, part 3, p. 13. 51. f. 84. 'Whether you walked by wastes of upland green'; n.d. Eight stanzas. Autograph (?). Published as 'Sorrow' in The G.K. Chesterton Quarterly, no. 30/31 (Spring/Summer 2004), p. 17. 52. ff. 85-86v. 'Who in the mirror would his features scan'; circa 1892. Three stanzas. 53. f. 87. 'Ye have made him a God in your shrine'; circa 1890. Three stanzas. 54. ff. 89-90v. 'You are the man that is marked with a star'; circa 1899. Eleven stanzas. The final six stanzas published as 'Chosen' in C.W, vol. 10, [part 1], pp. 343-344 and more fully in C.W, vol. 10, part 3, p. 42. 55. ff. 91-93. 'You will hear many tales'; n.d. Three stanzas. Typewritten copies, annotated by Dorothy Collins as 'discarded & unfinished verses'. Published in C.W, vol. 10, part 3, p. 314. 56. ff. 94-117. Fragments of poems; circa 1891 - circa 1910. Includes (f. 99) the third stanza and envoi of a ballade in French with the refrain 'Qu'elle est heureuse cette Madame Boore', which is published as 'Cyrano allez aux chiens' in C.W, vol. 10, [part 1], p. 431

G. K. CHESTERTON PAPERS. VOL. CXXXVI C. Poems and stories, many fragmentary, and sketches; circa 1892 . Includes: fragment of a verse play 'The Junior Debating Club: a morality' (see also Add. 73303 B) (ff. 2-5v); acrostics; poems 'Leonardo da Vinci' (published, with the draft continuation from Add. 73305 B, ff. 69-70v, in The G. K. Chesterton Quarterly, no. 7 (Summer 1998), p. 15 and in C.W , vol. 10, part 2, p. 142) (ff. 11-11v), 'St John's Wood march' (on his leaving Calderon's art college in St John's Wood) (ff. 19v-20; published in C.W , vol. 10, part 2, p. 167), 'Jesus of Nazareth' (see also Add MS 73303 A; published in The G. K. Chesterton Quarterly, no. 6 (Spring 1998), p. 1 and in C.W , vol. 10, part 2, p. 71) (ff. 28v-29), 'The six makers' (see references at Add. 73325 D) (ff. 100v-101v), 'The Caliph's Daughter' (published in The G. K. Chesterton Quarterly, no. 22 (Autumn 2002) and in C.W , vol. 10, part 2, p. 175) (f. 35), 'The present time' (see references at Add. 73322 B) (ff. 36-36v); an illustrated short story set in 1894 involving members of the Junior Debating Club (published in part as 'Our future prospects' in The G. K. Chesterton Quarterly, no. 15-20 (Summer 2000 - Autumn 2001) and published in full in Basil Howe (New City, 2001), (ff. 39-64v); a series of cartouches on Egyptian themes; fragmentary letters in French to E. C. Bentley (ff. 77v, 80v, 105v vol. rev.). Folios 42v (part) and 43v-44 are in the hand of Cecil Chesterton. The notebook is discussed in D. Barker, op. cit, p. 50. Text commences at both ends. ff. i+117. 255 x 235mm

LEONARDO DA VINCI, Trattato della Pittura, with the life of Leonardo [by Rafaelle Trichet du Fresne] prefixed and the set of drawings as engraved in Trichet du Fresne's edition, Paris, 1651. These illustrations, as explained in the dedication to the edition, were executed by [Charles] Errard, who availed himself in part of sketches by Nicholas Poussin contained in a MS. belonging to Signor di Ciantelou [Jean Fréard, Sieur de Chantelou, brother of Roland Freard, Sicur de Chambray, the French translator of Leonardo's work], to whom it was given by Cavaliere [Cassiano] dal Pozzo. There seems no obvious improbability in the statement in Bibliotheca Smithiana that this MS. 'è lo stesso che va alle stampe', implying that it contains Errard's drawings as sent to the printer (the shading is added by the engraver), but the same claim is apparently made for a MS. at Rome, Barberini 834 (see Manzis edition of the Arte della Pittura, Rome, 1817, p. 12). For an account of the other MSS. and editions, some of which have different drawings, see Manzi, op. cit . A tinted medallion portrait of Leonardo is on f. 1. Paper; ff. 137. Folio. 11 5 / 8 in. x 8 in. XVII cent. From the library of Joseph Smith, Consul at Venice, see Bibl. Smith , p. ccccxcix, col. i, where it is stated to have previously belonged to Padre Antonio Pellegrino Orlandi [1660-1727]. Half-bound in blue

Name: Leonardo da Vinci, artist, engineer, and scientist
All names: Howard, Henry, 6th Duke of Norfolk, 1628-1684 [former owner] ; Howard, Thomas, 2nd earl of Arundel, 4th earl of Surrey, and first earl of Norfolk, art collector and politician, 1585-1646 [former owner] ; Leonardo da Vinci, artist, engineer, and scientist, 1452-1519 [creator]
Title: Leonardo da Vinci, Notebook (''The Codex Arundel'')
Physical description: 1 paper codex; 283 folios ; Materials: Paper. Dimensions: c. 205 x 290 mm. Foliation: ff. 283. Script: Handwriting of Leonardo da Vinci (mirror writing). Binding: None: unbound bifolia
Notes: Contents:. Notebook of Leonardo da Vinci (''The Codex Arundel''). A collection of papers written in Italian by Leonardo da Vinci (b. 1452, d. 1519), in his characteristic left-handed mirror-writing (reading from right to left), including diagrams, drawings and brief texts, covering a broad range of topics in science and art, as well as personal notes. The core of the notebook is a collection of materials that Leonardo describes as ''a collection without order, drawn from many papers, which I have copied here, hoping to arrange them later each in its place according to the subjects of which they treat'' (f. 1r), a collection he began in the house of Piero di Braccio Martelli in Florence, in 1508. To this notebook has subsequently been added a number of other loose papers containing writing and diagrams produced by Leonardo throughout his career. Decoration: Numerous diagrams
Provenance: Origin: Italy (Florence, Milan, Rome) and France (Amboise). Provenance:. Leonardo da Vinci (b. 1452, d. 1519): writer of the collection of loose papers (most dating to 1508) which, since his death, have been gathered together to form this notebook. Thomas Howard (b. 1585, d. 1646), 2nd earl of Arundel, 4th earl of Surrey, and 1st earl of Norfolk, art collector and politician: owner. Henry Howard (b. 1628, d. 1684), 6th duke of Norfolk: presented the notebook to the Royal Society in 1667 (see below). The Royal Society, London: its ink stamp, ''Soc. Reg. Lond / ex dono HENR. HOWARD / Norfolciensis.'' (f. 2r); purchased by the British Museum from the Royal Society together with 549 other Arundel manuscripts in 1831

Topics: Clerkenwell, Middlesex ; Courci, John, conqueror of Ulster; d.?1219, -219 ; Malone Malachius, supposed Carmelite friar ; Mason, Samuel, of Add MS 4791 ; Sidney, Henry, Lord President of Wales, and Lord Deputy of Ireland ; Vinci, Leonardo da, of Add MS 4791 ; Ware, James, (?) son of Sir James Ware ; Ware, James, the younger; historian, -666 ; Ware, Robert, son of Sir J Ware, the younger
Notes: MILLES COLLECTION. Vol. XXXVIII (ff. i+ 210). Historical collections covering period 4th-17th centt. Clarendon MS. Vol. 44. There is a table of contents at f. 3. Also included are:-. (1) Papers forged by Robert Ware; circ. 1678:-(a) The confession of Malachius Malone, a converted Carmelite friar; 1584. Printed by Ware in Foxes and Firebrands, 1682, part ii, pp. 35-49. See T. E. Bridgett, op. cit, pp. 250-251. ff. 27-33; (b) Confession of Samuel Mason, a convert; 1566. See Foxes and Firebrands, part ii, pp. 15-35, and Bridgett, op. cit, pp. 245-250. ff. 34-37; (c) Memorial of Sir Henry Sidney. See Foxes and Firebrands, part ii, pp. 11-14, and Bridgett, op. cit, p. 284. f. 38; (d) Letter from the Privy Council to the Lord Deputy, 2 March 1627/8, relating to the Clerkenwell discovery, with a copy of the forged Jesuit letter. See Foxes and Firebrands, part ii, pp. 118-128, and Bridgett, op. cit, pp. 214-216. ff. 38b-40. (2) Life of Sir John de Courci, compiled from extracts from the Book of Howth, with other material from the same source; 17th cent. Cf. Cal. State Papers: Carew, Book of Howth, pp. 42-43, 104-115, 116, 117. ff. 41-61. (3) Extracts in the hand of Sir James Ware from the Annals of Boyle, 347-1240; early 17th cent. Irish and Latin. See S. H. O'Grady, op. cit, p. 15. ff. 162-174. (4) Engraving after a drawing by Leonardo da Vinci of a knot design, inscribed at the centre 'Academia Leonardi Vinci'; circ. 1483. Cf. Add. MS. 4795, f. 2. ff. 210. Heraldry: Arms of Sir J. Ware on bindings: 17th cent. Notes: MILLES COLLECTION. Vol. XLII (ff. 108). Annals of Ulster, 431-1307, partly in the autograph of Sir James Ware; 17th cent. Clarendon MS. Vol. 49. Title: Le Trait d'Union : Organe des Jeunesses de l'Inde Française Vol. 6, Issue 3 to Vol. 11, Issue 2, Jan 1950-Dec 1953
Notes: Missing issues: Vol. 8, issue 10; Vol. 9, issues 3, 8; Vol. 10, issues 3, 10. Vol. 10 issue 6 is wrongly numbered as issue 4. Vol. 8 contains a supplement issue 11bis. The volume contains short fictional and humorous pieces, poems, articles about Pondicherry and its history, local news and a column on 'News of Saigon', accounts of cultural and other events taking place in Pondicherry, book reviews, cartoons, announcements and advertisements etc. Some of the themes covered are: the monetary crisis stemming from the usage of two currencies in Pondicherry - the Indian rupee and the local rupee, some visions of India from the viewpoint of French India, a panorama of pharmacy in the Indian Union and traditional Indian medicinal drugs, French translation of Subramania Barathy's poems, the Pondicherry port, urbanism in Pondicherry, Hindu astrologers, commerce in Pondicherry, 'people and things of French India', Leonardo da Vinci, a military doctor from Pondicherry in the 18th cent, criminal justice in Pondicherry, the press in French India etc. There are also articles relating to Indian culture and mythology. Some of the topical events covered are: the demises of Ramana Maharshi, Sri Aurobindo, the prime minister of Pakistan Liaquat Ali Khan; election of the member of parliament (député) from French India to the French National Assembly etc. Some of the issues contain a few b&w photos, cartoons and drawings. 1 volume containing 43 issues and 1 supplement issue, approx. 390 pages in various pagings. Dimensions: 28 x 22 cm. All the pages of the Sept and Oct. 1950 issues and pages 9-10 of the Dec. 1951 issue have holes and p. 3 of the March 1952 issue is torn. A white sheet has been placed behind them so that a clear copy could be obtained. Also pages3-6 of the Feb.1953 issue are bound upside down and in reverse order
